description: From Middle English, from Old French noble, from Latin nōbilis (“knowable, known, well-known, famous, celebrated, high-born, of noble birth, excellent”), from nōscere, gnōscere (“to know”).
Displaced native Middle English athel, from Old English æþele.

adjectives.description: noble (comparative nobler or more noble, superlative noblest or most noble)

entries.meaning: Having honorable qualities; having moral eminence and freedom from anything petty, mean or dubious in conduct and character.
examples: He is a noble man who would never put his family in jeopardy.

entries.meaning: Of exalted rank; of or relating to the nobility; distinguished from the masses by birth, station, or title; highborn.
(geometry, of a polyhedron) Both isohedral and isogonal.
An aristocrat; one of aristocratic blood. [from 14th c.]
examples: This country house was occupied by nobles in the 16th century.

entries.meaning: (historical) A medieval gold coin of England in the 14th and 15th centuries, usually valued at 6s 8d. [from 14th c.]
examples: I lyked no thynge his playe, / For yf I had not quyckely fledde the touche, / He had plucte oute the nobles of my pouche.
